explanation:
The correct calculation multiplies weeks by days/week and hours/day: \( 10 \times 7 \times 24 \).

The student used \( 10 \times 5 \times 24 \), substituting 5 for 7 in the days/week conversion. This indicates they mistakenly believed there are 5 days in a week instead of 7. 

The error stems from using an incorrect days-per-week ratio (5 instead of 7) when converting weeks to days, a direct misapplication of the conversion factor. This aligns with confusing standard time units (a week is 7 days, not 5) rather than miscalculating multi-step conversions or using fractional days like 7.5. 

The mistake is specifically about substituting an erroneous days/week value, distinct from forgetting to convert weeks to days first or confusing hours with smaller units like minutes.
